keyTakeAways: Hamas returned the bodies of two Israeli hostages, Arie Zalmanowicz and Master Sgt (res) Tamir Adar, under a US-brokered ceasefire deal.
Zalmanowicz, 85, was abducted from Kibbutz Nir Oz and killed in captivity on 17 November 2023.
Adar, 38, died while resisting Hamas gunmen during the initial attack and was later taken to Gaza.
The return of these remains brings the total number of deceased Israeli hostages returned to 15 out of 28 under the first phase of the ceasefire.
The International Committee of the Red Cross facilitated the transfer of the coffins from Gaza to Israel.
Israel demands Hamas uphold the agreement and return all deceased hostages, citing outrage over incomplete deliveries.
Hamas claims it has difficulty locating Palestinian bodies buried in rubble due to Israeli bombing.
Under the ceasefire, Israel released 250 Palestinian prisoners and 1,718 detainees in exchange for 15 Palestinian bodies per Israeli hostage’s remains.
The ceasefire included increased aid to Gaza, a partial withdrawal of Israeli forces, and a halt in hostilities—though violence resumed over the weekend.
More than 68,000 people have been killed in Gaza since the initial attack, according to Hamas-run health ministry figures.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Israel is central to the conflict, as it was the victim of the Hamas attack and the party that negotiated and enforced the ceasefire agreement with Hamas.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Under a US-brokered ceasefire agreement, Israel has identified the bodies of two hostages taken during the Hamas-led attack on 7 October 2023: Arie Zalmanowicz, an 85-year-old man from Kibbutz Nir Oz who was killed in captivity, and Master Sgt (res) Tamir Adar, a 38-year-old community security officer who died resisting Hamas gunmen. Their remains, transferred via the International Committee of the Red Cross, mark 15 of the 28 deceased Israeli hostages returned under the first phase of the ceasefire. Israel demands Hamas fulfill its obligations to return all deceased hostages, citing outrage over incomplete deliveries, while Hamas claims it faces difficulties locating Palestinian bodies amid extensive rubble from Israeli bombing. The agreement also included the release of over 2,000 Palestinian prisoners and a partial withdrawal of Israeli forces, though violence has flared again. The conflict continues to claim over 68,000 lives in Gaza since October 2023, according to Hamas health ministry reports.
title: Israel identifies bodies of two hostages returned by Hamas
